articles.headline: Crop Yield Raises Risk to Food Cost
articles.snippet: Commodities experts said that the increases would ultimately lead to higher prices for staples like vegetable oil, pasta and meat
articles.abstract: Commodities experts said that the increases would ultimately lead to higher prices for staples like vegetable oil, pasta and meat
articles.lead_paragraph: Consumers can expect to see a jump in prices for pasta, meat, vegetable oil and many other grocery items in the coming months as a pair of new government reports forecast on Thursday that a brutal mixture of heat, drought or flooding has taken a toll on the corn, soybeans and wheat grown on American farms.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Is Disputed on Civilian Toll in Drone Strikes
articles.snippet: The civilian toll of the C.I.A.’s drone campaign in Pakistan has been in bitter dispute since the strikes were accelerated in 2008.
articles.abstract: The civilian toll of the C.I.A.’s drone campaign in Pakistan has been in bitter dispute since the strikes were accelerated in 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On May 6, a Central Intelligence Agency drone fired a volley of missiles at a pickup truck carrying nine militants and bomb materials through a desolate stretch of Pakistan near the Afghan border. It killed all the militants — a clean strike with no civilian casualties, extending what is now a yearlong perfect record of avoiding collateral deaths.

articles.headline: Sometimes, Inflation Is Not Evil
articles.snippet: Easing monetary policy has worsened the housing bubble and has not done much to revive the debt-choked economy over the last two years.
articles.abstract: Easing monetary policy has worsened the housing bubble and has not done much to revive the debt-choked economy over the last two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, you have to unlearn your lessons.

articles.headline: Protests Force Israel to Confront Wealth Gap
articles.snippet: Protesters in Israel complain that a country once seen as a model of equality now has one of the largest gaps between rich and poor in the industrialized world.
articles.abstract: Protesters in Israel complain that a country once seen as a model of equality now has one of the largest gaps between rich and poor in the industrialized world.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — They are mainstays of the society pages and glossy magazines. Some are praised for the hospital wings they have built, others are gossiped about for their quirks.

articles.headline: Investors Fret at Costs if Rescues Are Needed
articles.snippet: Ninety of Europe’s biggest banks hold $6.7 trillion in loans that are due in the next two years. That is more than half of the combined gross domestic product of the 17 nations that use the euro.
articles.abstract: Ninety of Europe’s biggest banks hold $6.7 trillion in loans that are due in the next two years. That is more than half of the combined gross domestic product of the 17 nations that use the euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ever since Lehman Brothers collapsed nearly three years ago, Europe’s leaders have repeatedly vowed to prevent any major European bank from failing.

articles.headline: Hot Chemotherapy Bath: Patients See Hope, Critics Hold Doubts
articles.snippet: As competition for patients and treatments intensifies, more medical centers are offering a controversial procedure in which inner organs are bathed in hot chemotherapy drugs.
articles.abstract: As competition for patients and treatments intensifies, more medical centers are offering a controversial procedure in which inner organs are bathed in hot chemotherapy drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — This is cancer therapy at its most aggressive, a treatment patients liken to being filleted, disemboweled and then bathed in hot poison.

articles.headline: As Dizzying Week Ends on Wall Street, Dangers Linger
articles.snippet: As a week of volatile trading drew to a close, many think the Wall Street roller coaster ride is likely to continue — and there may be more drops ahead.
articles.abstract: As a week of volatile trading drew to a close, many think the Wall Street roller coaster ride is likely to continue — and there may be more drops ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the most tumultuous weeks on Wall Street ended on Friday with the markets not that far from where they started, but with worries about the United States economy and the threat of a financial crisis in Europe undiminished.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Christine Hauser

articles.headline: Small Investors Recalibrate After Market Gyrations
articles.snippet: Small investors, the bedrock of the United States stock market, are being buffeted by the steep drops on Wall Street or bailing altogether as they worry about their money’s survival.
articles.abstract: Small investors, the bedrock of the United States stock market, are being buffeted by the steep drops on Wall Street or bailing altogether as they worry about their money’s survival.
articles.lead_paragraph: Small investors’ faith in the stock market is being tested again.

articles.headline: 8 From G.O.P. Trade Attacks at Iowa Debate
articles.snippet: Criticism of President Obama’s record was overshadowed by a burst of incivility among the Republican presidential candidates at a debate on Thursday in Ames, Iowa.
articles.abstract: Criticism of President Obama’s record was overshadowed by a burst of incivility among the Republican presidential candidates at a debate on Thursday in Ames, Iowa.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — A withering critique of President Obama’s handling of the economy was overshadowed by a burst of incivility among the Republican presidential candidates who gathered here for a debate on Thursday night and fought to stay alive in the party’s increasingly fractious nominating race.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Aftershock to Economy Has a Precedent That Holds Lessons
articles.snippet: Recent events bear an intriguing resemblance to 1937-38, and the recession within a Depression, which galvanized policy makers who had grown complacent about the recovery.
articles.abstract: Recent events bear an intriguing resemblance to 1937-38, and the recession within a Depression, which galvanized policy makers who had grown complacent about the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like earthquakes, financial crises seem to be accompanied by aftershocks, like the one we’ve been living through this week. They can feel every bit as bad as the crisis itself. But economic history and academic research suggest they can set the stage for a sustainable recovery — and eventual sharp stock market gains.
